snp3.11:1.1.eng: The seer Asita in his daily meditation
snp3.11:1.1.comm: Asita means “dark one”. He is an example of the “dark hermit” archetype.

snp3.11:1.2.eng: saw the bright-clad gods of the host of Thirty
snp3.11:1.2.comm: Bodhi and Norman follow the PTS reading sakkacca here, but it seems uncharacteristic to me. Why mention they have just honored Indra? On the other hand, it’s common to express “a group with its leader”.

snp3.11:1.3.eng: and their lord Sakka joyfully celebrating,

snp3.11:2.2.eng: he paid respects and said this there:

snp3.11:2.3.eng: “Why is the community of gods <j>in such excellent spirits?

snp3.11:2.4.eng: Why take up streamers and whirl them about?

snp3.11:3.1.eng: Even in the war with the titans,

snp3.11:3.2.eng: when gods were victorious and titans defeated,

snp3.11:3.4.eng: What marvel have the celestials seen <j>that they so rejoice?

snp3.11:4.1.eng: Shouting and singing and playing music,

snp3.11:4.2.eng: they clap their hands and dance.

snp3.11:4.3.eng: I ask you, dwellers on Mount Meru’s peak,

snp3.11:4.4.eng: quickly dispel my doubt, good fellows!”

snp3.11:5.1.eng: “The being intent on awakening, a peerless gem,

snp3.11:5.2.eng: has been born in the human realm <j>for the sake of welfare and happiness,

snp3.11:5.3.eng: in Lumbinī, a village in the Sakyan land.

snp3.11:5.4.eng: That’s why we’re so happy, in such excellent spirits.

snp3.11:6.1.eng: He is supreme among all beings, the peak individual,

snp3.11:6.2.eng: captain of men, supreme among all creatures.
snp3.11:6.2.comm: Narāsabha is literally “a bull of a man”, but the predominant sense is “chief”, “lord” rather than “bull”. Vṛṣabha was widely used in this sense as far back as the Rig Veda, unlike English, where “bull” conveys quite a different set of connotations. The same is true of its synonyms janavasabha and purisnisabha, but not purisūsabho at Bu Pj 1:10.21.4.

snp3.11:6.3.eng: He will roll forth the wheel in the grove of the seers,

snp3.11:6.4.eng: roaring like a mighty lion, lord of beasts.”

snp3.11:7.2.eng: and right away approached Suddhodana’s home.
snp3.11:7.2.comm: Notice the use of the humble bhavana rather than the royal pasāda. There is an almost complete lack of royal language in this text, the sole exception being the antepura (“royal compound”) in Snp 3.11:17.2.

snp3.11:7.3.eng: Seated there he said this to the Sakyans,

snp3.11:7.4.eng: “Where is the boy? I too wish to see him!”
snp3.11:7.4.comm: In DN 14:1.31.3, the bodhisatta Vipassī is examined by a number of brahmins.

snp3.11:8.1.eng: Then the Sakyans showed their son <j>to the one named Asita—

snp3.11:8.2.eng: the boy shone like burning gold

snp3.11:8.4.eng: dazzling with glory, of peerless beauty.

snp3.11:9.1.eng: The boy beamed like crested flame,

snp3.11:9.2.eng: pure as the moon, lord of stars traversing the sky,

snp3.11:9.3.eng: blazing like the sun free of stormclouds after the rains;
snp3.11:9.3.comm: Here, as so often, “autumn” (per Bodhi and Norman) conveys quite the wrong impression. Autumn is the time of gathering clouds, sarada is the time after the rains.

snp3.11:9.4.eng: seeing him, he was joyful, brimming with happiness.

snp3.11:10.1.eng: The celestials held up a parasol in the sky,

snp3.11:10.4.eng: but none could see who held <j>the chowries or the parasols.

snp3.11:11.1.eng: When the dreadlocked seer called “Dark Splendor”
snp3.11:11.1.comm: Jaṭī is an abbreviated form of jaṭila, a matted hair ascetic, usually Brahmanical.

snp3.11:11.2.eng: had seen the boy like a gold ingot on a cream rug
snp3.11:11.2.comm: Here the commentary glosses paṇḍu as ratta (“red”), followed by both Norman (“pale red”) and Bodhi. But paṇḍu means “pale, white, cream, yellowish” and I can’t see anywhere in Pali or Sanskrit to suggest a meaning “red”.

snp3.11:11.3.eng: with a white parasol held over his head,

snp3.11:11.4.eng: he received him, elated and happy.

snp3.11:12.2.eng: the seeker, master of marks and hymns,

snp3.11:12.3.eng: lifted up his voice with confident heart:

snp3.11:12.4.eng: “He is supreme, the best of men!”

snp3.11:13.1.eng: But then, remembering he would depart this world,

snp3.11:13.2.eng: his spirits fell and his tears flowed.

snp3.11:13.3.eng: Seeing the weeping seer, the Sakyans said,

snp3.11:13.4.eng: “Surely there will be no threat to the boy?”

snp3.11:14.1.eng: Seeing the crestfallen Sakyans, the seer said,

snp3.11:14.2.eng: “I do not forsee harm befall the boy,

snp3.11:14.3.eng: and there will be no threat to him,

snp3.11:14.4.eng: not in the least; set your minds at ease.

snp3.11:15.1.eng: This boy shall reach the highest awakening.

snp3.11:15.2.eng: As one of perfectly purified vision, <j>compassionate for the welfare of the many,

snp3.11:15.3.eng: he shall roll forth the wheel of the teaching;

snp3.11:15.4.eng: his spiritual path will become widespread.

snp3.11:16.1.eng: But I have not long left in this life,

snp3.11:16.3.eng: I will never hear the teaching of the one <j>who bore the unequaled burden.
snp3.11:16.3.comm: Neither Bodhi’s “fortitude” nor Norman’s “peerless one” quite capture the force of asamadhura. The implication is that, as the forger of the path, the Buddha carries a burden greater than any other.

snp3.11:16.4.eng: That’s why I’m so upset and distraught—<j>it’s a disaster for me!”

snp3.11:17.1.eng: Having brought abundant happiness to the Sakyans,

snp3.11:17.2.eng: the spiritual seeker left the royal compound.

snp3.11:17.3.eng: He had a nephew; and out of sympathy

snp3.11:17.4.eng: he encouraged him in the teaching <j>of the one who bore the unequaled burden.

snp3.11:18.1.eng: “When you hear the voice of another saying <j>‘Buddha’—
snp3.11:18.1.comm: Note the idiom parato ghosaṁ here.

snp3.11:18.2.eng: one who has attained awakening <j>and who reveals the foremost teaching—
snp3.11:18.2.comm: This is a succinct definition of buddha, not an alternate thing that you might hear people say, per Bodhi and Norman.

snp3.11:18.3.eng: go there and ask about his breakthrough;
snp3.11:18.3.comm: Both Norman and Bodhi have “doctrine” here, while commentary is silent. I’m not aware of samaya in the sense of “doctrine” in the early texts, nor is it listed in the senses of samaya in the commentarial analysis in the Dhammasaṅgaṇī commentary, Kāmāvacarakusala. Given that the concern in previous lines is the notion of an awakened one, surely we have here an abbreviated abhisamaya i.e. “breakthrough, enlightenment experience”.

snp3.11:18.4.eng: lead the spiritual life under that Blessed One.”

snp3.11:19.1.eng: Now, that Nālaka had a store of accumulated merit;

snp3.11:19.2.eng: so when instructed by one of such kindly intent,
snp3.11:19.2.comm: I find it curious that this epithet is used of both the Buddha and Asita.

snp3.11:19.3.eng: with perfectly purified vision of the future,

snp3.11:19.4.eng: he waited anticipating the Victor, <j>guarding his senses.

snp3.11:20.1.eng: When he heard of the Victor rolling forth <j>the excellent wheel he went to him,

snp3.11:20.2.eng: and seeing the boss seer, he became confident.

snp3.11:20.3.eng: The time of Asita’s instruction had arrived;

snp3.11:20.4.eng: so he asked the excellent sage <j>about the highest sagacity.

snp3.11:21.2.eng: have turned out to be true.

snp3.11:21.4.eng: who has gone beyond all things:

snp3.11:22.1.eng: For one who has entered the homeless life,

snp3.11:22.3.eng: when questioned, O sage, please tell me

snp3.11:22.4.comm: Bodhi accepts the commentarial gloss of pada as paṭipadā here, but I find his reasoning unconvincing. Yes, the text speaks of practice, but this correlates to the first part of the answer. Here, at the end of the question, it relates to the end of the text, which speaks of the state of sagacity.

snp3.11:23.4.eng: Come, I shall tell you all about it.

snp3.11:24.1.eng: In the village, keep the same attitude

snp3.11:24.2.eng: no matter if reviled or praised.

snp3.11:25.1.comm: Note that, despite the etymology, uccāvaca seems to be used more in the sense of “diversity” rather than “high and low”; eg. the colors of a rainbow. Here all things are like tongues of flame, i.e. there are many different ones, but they are not treated as better or worse.

snp3.11:25.2.eng: like tongues of fire in a forest.

snp3.11:25.3.eng: Women try to seduce a sage—

snp3.11:26.2.eng: having left behind sensual pleasures high and low,

snp3.11:26.4.eng: to living creatures firm or frail.

snp3.11:27.2.eng: as are they, so am I’—

snp3.11:27.4.eng: neither kill nor incite to kill.

snp3.11:28.2.eng: for what ordinary people are attached to,
snp3.11:28.2.comm: As other instances of this line make clear, the referent of yattha is kāmā, i.e. the pleasures of the senses, not the desire and greed (of the previous line). Bodhi gets this nuance right, Norman does not.

snp3.11:28.3.eng: one whose eye is clear would set out to practice,

snp3.11:28.4.comm: For naraka here, Bodhi has “inferno”, Norman “hell”; but the metaphor of “crossing over” better fits the normal sense of “cliff” or “abyss” (MN 49:5.9, mn86:6.15](), Thag 16.8:4.2). Notably, naraka is not strongly attested in the sense of “hell” for pre-Buddhist Sanskrit either, although we do find nāraka, apparently in the sense of “hell being”, at Atharva Veda 12.4.36c and Śukla Yajur Veda 30.5.

snp3.11:29.1.eng: With empty stomach, taking limited food,

snp3.11:30.2.eng: they’d take themselves into the forest;

snp3.11:30.3.eng: and nearing the foot of a tree,

snp3.11:30.4.eng: the sage would take their seat.

snp3.11:31.1.eng: That attentive one intent on absorption,

snp3.11:31.3.eng: They’d practice absorption at the foot of a tree,

snp3.11:32.1.eng: Then, at the end of the night,

snp3.11:32.2.eng: they’d take themselves into a village.

snp3.11:32.3.comm: This line and the next echo the practices of Jain ascetics: naehibhaddantiko, natiṭṭhabhaddantiko, nābhihaṭaṁ. The sense of the first two terms is similar to avhāna, while the last of these terms is the same as abhihāra in the next line.

snp3.11:32.4.eng: nor offerings brought from the village.

snp3.11:33.1.eng: A sage who has come to a village

snp3.11:33.2.eng: would not walk hastily among the families.
snp3.11:33.2.comm: Bodhi’s “should not behave rashly” and Norman’s “should not pursue his search for food inconsiderately” confuse a plain meaning. When on alms round a mendicant should not walk too fast, else the families have no time to ready the food.

snp3.11:33.3.eng: They’d not discuss their search for food,

snp3.11:34.4.eng: they return right to the tree.

snp3.11:35.2.eng: not dumb, but thought to be dumb,

snp3.11:35.3.eng: they wouldn’t scorn a tiny gift,

snp3.11:35.4.eng: nor look down upon the giver.

snp3.11:36.1.eng: For the practice has many aspects,
snp3.11:36.1.comm: As above, uccāvaca probably means “diverse” practices rather than “high and low” per commentary followed by Bodhi and Norman. The only usage of uccāvaca in the context of practice is the “diverse duties” performed by mendicants for their fellows (eg. DN 33:3.3.17).

snp3.11:36.2.comm: Norman’s proposal that this is not the Buddha is implausible.

snp3.11:36.3.eng: They do not go to the far shore twice,
snp3.11:36.3.comm: This verse is quoted by the Kathāvatthu (Kv 1.2:113.1) to refute the thesis that an arahant might fall away from their attainment. This is overlooked by both Bodhi and Norman, although it evidently underlies the commentary.

snp3.11:36.4.eng: nor having gone once do they fall away.
snp3.11:36.4.comm: Both Bodhi and Norman discuss this line, without any compelling conclusion. The problematic mutaṁ cannot mean “experienced” per Bodhi and Norman following the commentary. Since the Kathāvatthu is by far the earliest source on this verse, I suggest we adopt its reading that the verse is about “falling away”, and amend mutaṁ to cutaṁ.

snp3.11:37.1.eng: When a mendicant has no creeping,

snp3.11:37.2.eng: and has cut the stream of craving,

snp3.11:37.3.eng: and given up all the various duties,

snp3.11:37.4.eng: no fever is found in them.

snp3.11:38.1.eng: I shall school you in sagacity.
snp3.11:38.1.comm: The PTS edition, as does the BJT, has a reciter’s remark here identifying the speaker as the Buddha, and this is translated without comment by Norman and Bodhi. It is unusual, if not unique, to find such a mark in the middle of a series of verses by one speaker. The Mahāsaṅgīti edition, following the VRI, lacks this remark and I have translated accordingly.

snp3.11:38.2.eng: Practice as if you were licking a razor’s edge.

snp3.11:38.3.eng: With tongue pressed against the roof of your mouth,

snp3.11:39.3.eng: Be free of putrefaction and unattached,

snp3.11:40.5.eng: you’ll light up the ten directions.

snp3.11:41.1.eng: Having heard the words of the attentive,
snp3.11:41.1.comm: By forcing the commentary’s sense of kitti into nigghosa, Bodhi and Norman confuse a simple meaning. Nighosa (more commonly spelled nigghosa) just means “word, teaching, statement”, eg. tava sutvāna nigghosaṁ “having heard your teaching”.

snp3.11:41.2.eng: the meditators who’ve given up sensual desires,

snp3.11:41.3.eng: a follower of mine would develop

snp3.11:41.4.eng: conscience and faith all the more.

snp3.11:42.1.eng: Understand this by the way streams move

snp3.11:42.3.eng: the little creeks flow on resounding,

snp3.11:42.4.eng: while silent flow the great rivers.

snp3.11:43.2.eng: what is full is at peace.

snp3.11:43.3.eng: The fool is like a half-full pot;

snp3.11:43.4.eng: the wise like a brimfull lake.

snp3.11:45.1.eng: But one who, knowing, is self-controlled,

snp3.11:45.3.eng: that sage is worthy of sagacity,
